metadata.name: MetaScaffold Metadata
metadata.description: Metadata for the meta scaffold combining general information and implementation principles.

value.purpose: A flexible taxonomy system for LLM agents ensuring structured and validated knowledge organization.
value.usage: Used for knowledge organization, hierarchical classification, LLM adaptation, and AI-driven decision-making.

corePrinciples.name: Domain Independence
corePrinciples.description: Taxonomies do not inherit biases from specific knowledge domains.

corePrinciples.name: Structural Consistency
corePrinciples.description: Maintain hierarchical order and logical classification rules.

corePrinciples.name: Flexible Adaptation
corePrinciples.description: Dynamic restructuring based on new knowledge.

data.name: Taxonomy Data
data.description: Structured taxonomy data including hierarchical ranks and classification criteria.

subsections.name: Hierarchical Structure
subsections.description: Defines the overall organization of taxonomic elements.
subsections.value: Dynamic organization of taxonomy elements. Use this to outline the overall layout and relationships among different taxonomic ranks.

subsections.name: Hierarchical Ranks
subsections.description: Levels of taxonomy from foundational to specialized.
subsections.value: Defines various levels for categorizing entities. Use this to select the appropriate rank based on the required granularity.

subsections.name: Foundational Ranks
subsections.description: The highest taxonomy level containing universal categories.
subsections.value: Foundational Rank - The highest level of classification that determines the broadest taxonomic categories. Use this for initial broad categorization.

subsections.name: Supreme Tier
subsections.description: Determines the most universal and inclusive categories.
subsections.value: Supreme Tier - The broadest classification level. Use this for establishing overarching, inclusive categories.

subsections.name: Principal Tier
subsections.description: Primary domain-independent categories that form the backbone of the taxonomy.
subsections.value: Principal Tier - High-level categories that distinguish main conceptual divisions. Use this for organizing the taxonomy into major segments.

subsections.name: Core Ranks
subsections.description: Primary categories that define essential properties.
subsections.value: Core Ranks - Fundamental grouping based on structural and functional attributes. Use this for grouping entities with shared core characteristics.

subsections.name: Fundamental Stratum
subsections.description: Categorizes entities based on structural differentiation and stable attributes.
subsections.value: Fundamental Stratum - Use for classifying elements based on inherent structural features and persistent attributes.

subsections.name: Primary Stratum
subsections.description: Groups elements based on core functionality and interdependencies.
subsections.value: Primary Stratum - Use for classification that emphasizes functional roles and relational integrity among entities.

subsections.name: Intermediate Ranks
subsections.description: Mid-level categories for more detailed classification.
subsections.value: Intermediate Ranks - Provides further granularity when core categories need refinement. Use this when additional specificity is required.

subsections.name: Essential Class
subsections.description: Classification based on core similarity and contextual stability.
subsections.value: Essential Class - Use for grouping entities that share fundamental characteristics and remain stable across contexts.

subsections.name: Cohesive Class
subsections.description: Groups entities that exhibit consistent behavioral alignment.
subsections.value: Cohesive Class - Use when elements show similar responses to system-wide influences, ensuring coherent grouping.

subsections.name: Specialized Ranks
subsections.description: The most granular taxonomy level representing specific entities.
subsections.value: Specialized Ranks - Use for precise classification of unique or highly specific entities.

subsections.name: Primary Entity
subsections.description: Represents a unique unit with minimal internal variation.
subsections.value: Primary Entity - Use for classification when an entity exhibits a distinct identity with minimal variation.

subsections.name: Variant Entity
subsections.description: Represents entities with recognizable deviations while maintaining core identity.
subsections.value: Variant Entity - Use for cases where an entity deviates from the norm yet retains its fundamental characteristics.

subsections.name: Classification Criteria
subsections.description: Rules governing the taxonomy for ensuring logical and systematic organization.
subsections.value: Defines the structural, functional, and semantic rules for taxonomy classification. Use this to guide the classification process.

subsections.name: Structural Criteria
subsections.description: Rules that ensure the structural integrity of the taxonomy.
subsections.value: Structural Criteria - Use these rules to verify clear hierarchical levels and distinct boundaries. They ensure no overlap between categories.

subsections.name: Hierarchical Determinacy
subsections.description: Defines clear levels of subordination and boundary clarity.
subsections.value: Hierarchical Determinacy - Use this to ensure that each taxonomic level is well-defined and non-overlapping.

subsections.name: Modular Composition
subsections.description: Ensures logical separation and independent composition of taxonomy modules.
subsections.value: Modular Composition - Use this to validate that each module is self-contained and integrates well with the overall taxonomy.

subsections.name: Functional Criteria
subsections.description: Rules based on the operational roles of taxonomy elements.
subsections.value: Functional Criteria - Use these rules to group elements by shared functionality and operational dependencies.

subsections.name: Behavioral Connectivity
subsections.description: Groups elements based on similar functional behavior and dependencies.
subsections.value: Behavioral Connectivity - Use this to classify entities that operate in a similar manner or depend on each other functionally.

subsections.name: Semantic Criteria
subsections.description: Rules that ensure semantic cohesion and conceptual clarity.
subsections.value: Semantic Criteria - Use these rules to maintain conceptual integrity and prevent semantic drift.

subsections.name: Lexical Similarity
subsections.description: Ensures retention of original meaning and proper mapping of synonyms.
subsections.value: Lexical Similarity - Use this to check that similar terms are correctly grouped and preserve their intended meaning.

subsections.name: Ontological Connectedness
subsections.description: Ensures that related concepts share a common ontological foundation.
subsections.value: Ontological Connectedness - Use this to validate that related taxonomy elements have a shared definitional base.

subsections.name: Semantic Drift Detection
subsections.description: Detects changes in the meaning of terms over time.
subsections.value: Semantic Drift Detection - Use this to monitor for shifts in concept meaning via methods like embedding distance tracking and contextual reclassification.

metaPrompts.name: Meta Instructions
metaPrompts.description: Meta instructions and prompts for validating and transforming the taxonomy for LLM agents.

subsections.name: Validation Rules
subsections.description: Instructions for ensuring taxonomy integrity.
subsections.value: Follow these guidelines to validate taxonomy structure, semantics, and relationships.

subsections.name: Structural Validation
subsections.description: Ensure hierarchical consistency and absence of cycles.
subsections.value: You must ensure that every element has a valid parent and that no cyclic dependencies exist. Verify that each taxonomic level is properly linked.

subsections.name: Semantic Validation
subsections.description: Ensure semantic cohesion and proper grouping of similar concepts.
subsections.value: You must check that similar concepts are grouped together and that synonyms are consolidated. Ensure semantic coherence and prevent duplicate entries.

subsections.name: Relational Validation
subsections.description: Ensure the logical validity of relationships between elements.
subsections.value: You must ensure that every relationship between taxonomy elements is meaningful and follows defined semantic rules. Flag any conflicting dependencies.

subsections.name: Meta Rules
subsections.description: High-level rules for taxonomy transformation and overall validation.
subsections.value: Follow these overarching rules to maintain logical integrity during taxonomy transformations.

subsections.name: Validation System
subsections.description: Guidelines for comprehensive taxonomy validation.
subsections.value: You must follow the validation system by ensuring hierarchy consistency, relationship integrity, and concept alignment throughout the taxonomy.

subsections.name: Transformation System
subsections.description: Guidelines for dynamically modifying the taxonomy.
subsections.value: Use these guidelines to merge, split, or restructure taxonomy elements while preserving logical consistency and structural integrity.
